8 minute read

I didnâ€™t know if it was because my analysis was so off that she didnâ€™t know where to begin? Or was she afraid of giving away secrets (am I missing something crucial)?

I StoppedÂ Reading Only the Mainstream Blogs

OnceÂ I got the fundamentals down, I realized that my skillset was stagnant. I knew all of the terms, had grown sites to millions in organic traffic, but needed more.

How many of you recognize these names?

  • Jon Mellen
  • Stephan Mack
  • Jamie Cottle
  • Kaitlin McMichael
  • Peter Wyspianski
  • Steve Bates

The names above represent some of the greatest minds in SEO: Nike, TripAdvisor, Getty Images, and Amazon. For the most part (minus Kaitlin, while she worked for Portent), many of the names above are non-existent on the popular blog sites.

  • Did Steve BatesÂ write an article when NikeÂ became the worlds largest shoe site? What about an article on how they used SQL + Visual mapping to make architectural changes that led to better crawling and more indexing?

Thatâ€™s right: I read job descriptions ğŸ™‚

The best companies normallyÂ donâ€™t give away their secrets â€“ unless itâ€™s in a job description.

Personally, I will read a Growth / SEO job description over a blog article on â€œ9 Billions SEO hacksÂ â€¦â€ anyday. Why? Because you learn so much more. You also learn what the company is focusing on (youâ€™re basically reading the rubric to their upcoming projects).

Reading job descriptions is humbling.

Sure, read the ones you are qualified and pat yourself on the back. But when you dig in and read the job descriptions like the ones above, youâ€™re head will quickly start to deflate and youâ€™ll have plenty to work on. Itâ€™s in this place you start to learn.

So what did I do after I failed? I went back â€“ re-read the job description and quickly realized that I was no-where near qualified.Â I started thinkingÂ like:

  • â€œWhat in the world is HIVE?â€
  • â€œHow would an SEO use SQL to analyze data?â€
  • â€œItâ€™s notÂ illegal to crawlÂ a portion of TripAdvisor â€“ lets get a massive list of URLs and put them in Excel and analyze them.â€
  • â€œOh waitâ€¦ Excel crashes with that many URLs.â€
  • â€œAhhhâ€¦ Thatâ€™s why they use SQLâ€

It was asking those questions that led to a greater understanding of SEO. I quickly learned that large site / e-commerce SEO was less about reading the latest content or link-building piece, and more aboutÂ solving problems with large data sets. It was about:

AfterÂ being declined for the job, I stopped consuming every piece of content marketing. I stayed up to date with the major publications and am grateful to those blogs for having a solid understanding of SEO, but I spentÂ my time reading job descriptions that I was not qualified for and started:

  • Learning more technicalÂ skills. Iâ€™m not going to write C, but SQL, JS â€“ yea, I can do that.
  • Playing with large data sets and trying to find problems and patterns.
  • Started reading over robots.txt files to analyzeÂ what sites were hiding (which by the way, has led to some of the greatest discounts available! Thatâ€™s where mostÂ hide their promo pages).
  • Started paying close attention to the structure of largers sites (crawlability = indexation = higher rankings).

I also started thinking about the problems they faced (and the skill-set they were seeking):

  • â€œAre the worried about link-building?â€ Probably not in the way I think of it. One link from abc.com wouldnâ€™t move the needle.
  • â€œWhat if their bigger problem was the distribution of those backlinks among their key pages?â€

It was thoughts like the above that trained my thinking to look for bigger the issues. I spent less time thinking content marketing, #SEO and more time thinking data analysis and hypothesis.

Did it work?

A few years later, I did end up getting a job offer from a larger commerce site in SEO (in fact, one listed above).

I turned it down.

However, the skills I had acquired from reading those job descriptions led to the type of job you dream of.
